div.head: H.B.M.'s CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Yesterday, Mr Vitt. Dimitri was charged before H. B. M.'a Consoler Conr', Cairo, with assanltiog and attempting to strike Antoine Kahii and Memetallah Bittar, louai snbjeots. Me. Sciortioo repreaented the complaioanla, the defenoi being condocted by Mr. Morris Palier, soliciter.

Jacques Mondolfo wu also oalled and aworn. He statrd that he saw two men fighting in the bar, and défendant trying to separate them. Two polioemen comiog in eeirud défendant and arrested him. Complaisant came to hia office next day and uked for his evidence.

Vittorio Dimitri eleoted to give evidence on hia own bchalf. He stated that he wu sitting ontside the New Bar at abont 8 p m. on the 14th inst., when he board a coiss at an adjoining table. Lo ïking round be saw Bittar strike Mahmoud Ali Bey. Bittar waa then felled, bat rose aod laid abont him with a oh tir. Witneas rose and aeis».d the chair, fearing hemight be strnok. Kahii came up and told him not to meddle, addiog tbat be waa a dangerona charaotor, eta, etc ; he then called two polioemen, whom be told to arreat him. Thia they did despi te his protests. After-ward Kahii apologised for his langoage. He absolctely denied the charges made.

Mr. J. Peldmann, oalled for the defence,eaid he wu présent the whole lime and saw défendant eeits the chair from Bittar. He heard Kahii ose offensivo langoage, but saw no usanlt or attempt at uiaclt on the part of défendant. Rj'sio Borsa, Italien sobject, cotrahorated ail Mr. Peldmann'a statements and added that he saw Bittar strike Mshmond Bey on the terrace of the Continental Hôtel.
The Conrt then stated that no fnrtber evidence wu required. There was no groond for a charge of usanlt or attempted usanlt, and both charges were dismissed.

King George has paid a visit to the Pope.

div.head: NORWAY'S INTEGRITY.
div.p: The "Tageblatt" states that King Haakon has issued circulars to the Powers asking for a guarantee of Norway's integrity. Rossi, Prance, and Germany have already assented.

div.head: SEVASTOPOL MUTINY.
div.p: 228 participants in the last matiry here have received sentences of varying terms of imprisonment: the men of the disciplinary battalions were sentenced to penal servitude for life. Two soldiers who shot a civilian were hanged. (Reuter)

div.head: TRAMWAY STRIKE IN CANADA.
div.p: Fifty men were wounded in a conflict with tramway strikers in Hamilton (Ontario). The Militia is protecting the cars. The strikers partly w. ad depot with dynamite. (P.)

div.head: FRENCH SCHOOLSHIP DESTROYED.
div.p: A fire has destroyed the school hip Algeciras. Three sailors were burned alive. (Hons)

div.head: THE SUEZ CANAL SHARES.
div.p: Sir,-As a Liberal organ, the Tribune" i to be commended, let alone exeu e', for the rough shod manrer in which it sums Disme'i's "sharp stock-broker trick." With all-due deference to the scruples of the older school of Conservatives, and to the feelings of the "Tribane," the fact remains that that "stockbroker's trick"-in which, by the bye, the Earl of Beacon field did not make a half-penny of brokerage was, I t-ke it, unparalleled in history. What would have happened to England if we bad not sneaked those 177 621 shares, as far as her position as a seapower and Asiatio Empire was concerned, it would have he bard to tell. It was tor Surz that we intervened in 1882, and it was for Sacz that we qusbbled with Turkey not so long ago. But for Dizzy." France might to-day have restored the Egyptian cor quests of Napoleon, changed the course of Near Eastern politics, and barred the Way to Indis.

In any case the Suez Canal was a vital necessity to our over seas dominion; once it was dug, we had to capture it sooner or later. Beaconsfie'd articipated British diplomacy; and his stock-broker's trick avoided what sooner or later would have led to a conflagration throngh cat Barope..

div.head: EGYPTIAN EXPLORATION.
div.p: The report of the season's work of the Egyp tian exploring party sent to Nubia by the University of Chicago, is a record of most systematic work. I be director of the work was Dr. J. H. Breasted, a learned Egyptologist, and the party were equipped with the best scientific apparatus, one of the chief objects of the work being to obtain photographs of every monament and inscription. The region selected for exploration was that lying along the Nile bank from Wady Halfs to Arsonar, being the ancient kingdom of Lower Nubis, and no fewer than eighteen temples were explored and photogra bed.

From the days of the Early Empire the Pharaohs bat csat hungry eyes on the regions of the Upser Nile, both on account of its wealth in gold, ivory, and strange products and animals, and also as a reoruiting ground, for, from the time of the sixth dynasty, the backbone of the Egyptian Army was the Nabian, as now it is the Sadacese. It was, however, the kings of the twelfth dynasty who first established rule over Nubia, and Dr. Breasted found many interesting records of the frontier ralers. In the grottoes at Kasr Ibrim there is a scene representing the recapture of the Nabian tribute. The amounts of the tribate are given in man-loads, a most unusual mode of counting. Thus we have a thousand men bearing ivory, two hundred and fifty laden with perfomes and aromatic woods. Among the articles of tribute are gold, ivory, ebony, panthers, bounds, oxen, and cattle. The total was two thonsand six hundred and sixty-seven man-loads. A truly large caravan. Of the goldproducing character of this region an interesting record is found of a governor who bears the title "Governor of the Gold Country of Amur," showing that the region was the fief of the great Sheban god.

The great rook-out temple of Rameses II. at Abou Simbel is one of the wonders of the world, rivalling in its sculptured halls the caves of E'ephants. The expedition made most thorough examination of this great building. Here a number of inscriptions of the grestest importance were for the first time accurately copied. The record of the great battle of Kadesh, in which the Egyptians stemmed the tide of Asiatic invaders, covers the walls of one hall, On another is the account of the marriage of Rameses II. with the daughter of the Hittite King. Dr. Breasted points out one corious passage, in which the king prays that in the winter journey of the Hittites to Egypt they may not be hindered by "rain or snow." It is doub ful if the Egyptians who read this passage could form any idea of what snow was, for I have found it quite impossible to make the Arabs understand the nature of ice or snow. In addition to the survey of the temple, a large number of rock cut stele and inscriptions were copied and photographed.

Next in importance to the work at Abou Simbel was that at Amads, where the great eighteenth dynasty temple was cleared of rabbish, planned, and photographed. One very interesting record here found was the record of the celebration of the second Jubilee of Thothmes IV. Of great importance was the discovery of several inscriptions relating to the latter end of the reign of Meneptab, generally regarded as the Phara h of the Exodus. These documents show that at the end of this Phsrach's reign there was great trouble in the land. After nearly four months' hard work, the expedition reached Assouan, having made a thorough arch logical survey of one of the most interesting provinces of Egypt. The resulta will be of the greatest value in restoring the early history of the Upper Nile pro vinces and the whole work is a good beginning of the New World's exploration of the Old. (W. St. C: Boscawen in the "Globe.")

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limitafree discussion.

div.head: NATIVES AND EUROPEANS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir, I remark with a certain amusement that Sheikh Ali Youssef has been kindled to melting heat by "Ottoman," and now asserts that letters like those penned by him and an "anknown Englishman" writing ander the "nom de guerre" of "Gael" are the cause and origin of every species of trouble in the body politic. Owing to them an American has been rade to an Egyptian in a railway train, and this prodigy is doubtless the first of a series, portending natural convulsions, schisms, and I know not what other catastrophes.

Bat while the excellent and learned Sheikh is ready to furnish each effect with its cause, and to defend the whole Egyptian nationwhich was never criticised-he has given us no reason for supposing that the acts of "goujaterie" often perpetrated at the expense of Syrian and European ladies by a certain class of native meet with the open reprobation of their fellows, and has not explained why none of these incidents has ever been taken ap by the Nationalist press.

Had the learned Sheikh addressed some of his co-religionists in regard to any such oecurrences as those notified by the "Journal da Caire" and other French newspapers as having occurred in Cairo during the past six months, and pointed out that their conduct was not only disgracefal in itself bat injurious. to the fair fame of their countrymen, he would have done his duty, and, would have deserved well of the public. But when a young Tunisian is knocked about by a Bey for object: ing to his unpleasant advances towards his sister, when European girls are persecuted in the Mousky by certain ill mannered Egyptians, our contemporary is silent. His thonders are reserved for Mr. Dunlop or any other béte noire of the day who ventores to differ from the Editor of "Al Moayad" in matters political.

Now I cannot accept Sheikh Youssef's view that the "noble and superb" conduct of an Egyptian (name not given) who was recently insalted by an American (unknown) in a train, one day, somewhere between Alexandria or Port Said and Cairo, absolves a certain class of Egyptians from the imputations made in a former letter. I say a, certain class emphatically, for I never accused all Egyptians of ill manners towards European women, but maintained that the obtrusive ill manners of a certain class of Egyptian were fatally certain to be regarded by Raropeans as symptomatic. These Baropeans would conolade, from what was thrust upon their notice, that the whole educated class was untrustworthy in these matters. Their conclusion would be inaccurate -though natural-bat, as I pointed out, the procosses by which one arrives at a conclusion are of slight importance compared with the conclusion itself. I grant the inaccuracy of all such generalisations; one of Al Moayad's" contributors would have us believe that all British officials greet moodirs and other notables pipe in mouth, their trousers turned ap, heaven knows how high, their clothes in disarray, while their pet dogs add a peculiar sacrilegiousness to the inurbanity of their masters. What a scene, Sir, for a caricatarist 11 have some excellent designs in my mind's eys and aball be happy to dispose of them for a consideration to any Nationalist artist of conme, replacing the heads of the native grandee and the uncaltared Briton by blank ovala. In this way the same cartoon may be used over and over again-with heads according to taste. The pipe, the turned ap trousers, and all the other properties will be analterable, but the dog might be allowed to vary with his master. Thus, if my hypothetical and, I hope, generona cartoonist were engaged in a campaign against the Ministry of the Interior he would limn the well-known features of Mr. Machell who would be accompanied by an Erment dog of the purest breed. If the Ministry of Finance were under the lash Sir Vincent Corbett and his amiable sachshand could be held up to publie oontumely, and if the Ministry of Education were involvedbat so, Sir 1-after perusing what the profession describes as "sample cattings" I simply dare not speculate as to what might be the character of the Adviser's canine friend. I have visions of the Hound of the Baskervilles, of the "Manthe Doog." or of Cerberus himselt, his beads and jawa wreathed in conformity with the Horatian description in Nationalist texts, squatting by Mr. Dunlop's feet and grinning with multitadinous fangs and triple insolence at a petrified notable.

Bat to return to the gentleman who was insulted by somebody somewhere. When I learn that his superb conduct is "in itself a disproof of the unjustifiable socusations directed against the entire Egyptian people" after repeating "ad nauseam meam" that nobody ever meant to insalt or accuse the whole Egyptian people. I must point out that the logic of the above remark is on a par with that of the Athenian worthy who, being anxious to sell his farm, came into town with a solitary brick as a sample of the property. However, I am very glad to learn that the Egyptian behaved politely and very sorry to hear that "Al Moayad" thinks that the rade American must have resd my letters. Hoping that we shall have no plagues or other calamities in consequence thereof-I remain, eto. "GAEL."

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING.
div.p: The report of the Sudan Gold Field, Limited, for the year to June 30th states that the mining and general expenditure, including depreciation, was £19,980, or, after the deduc tion of various cash receipts, a ret amount of $18,404. In addition there was expended:- On building, macbinery and plant, £3,316; railway, plant and rolling stock, £438; surface and mine works, £1,116; machinery and goods in transit, £297. At June 30th the sum of 12. per share had been called up on the 15,000 shares representing the working capi tal, and the financial position then stood as follows:-8a. per share uncalled, £52,000; balance of calls in arrear, £6,500; cash at bankers, etc., £2,391; total, £70,981; less: Received in anticipation of calle, £23; liabili ties, £831, leaving a balance of working capital of £70,037. The summary of work done daring the twelve months shows 1,954 ft. of sinking and 1,732 ft. of driving, or a total of 3.686 ft. The matter of the water supply, which necessarily is one of the utmost import ance, has received c'ose attention, and a deaided improvement has taken place during the twelve months. At the Geriafat wel', situated some 5 miles from the mine, the available supply bas increased to 3,000 gallons per 24 hours. This is conveyed to the mine by means of a pipe line. At the Muftah well, situated midway between No. 6 station and the mine, the supply at a depth of 182 ft. is at the rate of 60 gallons per 24 hours. It will be remembered that the ancients, by means of the large excavations along the reefs, extracted the balk of the quartz so rendered available, and as in some instances these workings reach the present 120 ft. level, the reserves of ore at the moment are not large. The mine continues to develop in a satisfactory manner, and, in the opinion of the two mining engineers, there is every probability of Om Nabardi proving a successful undertaking. Tae company's financial position is satisfactory. Egyptian Mines Exploration Company. Mr. C. J. Alford has farnished the following summary of the month's operations:- Semas mine, November 1-Work resumed. Main Shafc-First level east 63 ft., vein in face 54 ins. wide assays 5.25 dw's. gold per ton. First level west 77 ft., vein 36 ipe, wide, 13 dwte. Main winzs down 17 ft. below first level, vein wider than 5ft. side of winze assays 53 dwts. gold per ton. No. 1 shaft first level west 185 ft., vein in face 12 ins. wide assays 34 dwts, gold. No. 3 shaft first level east 146 ft., vein 84 ins. with 6.5 dwts. gold per toa. The first level will be connected throughoat as quickly as possible, opening about 900 ft. of vein; then more wit ze to the second level-250 ft. in main shaft-will be com-j menced.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: E. T. C. v. A. S. C.

The second fixture between the above teams was played off on Saturday at the Sporting Clab and after a keenly contested game resalted the same as the first, namely, a draw of one goal each The B.T.C. team kicked off, and immediately after found themselves defeading, though no score resulted from the effort. After this the teams were taking almoet alternate rushes at their opponents' goal and in one Barnard was conspicuous on the right wing, taking the ball well up the field and centred the same nicely, but no score was effected. After the goal-kick the B.T.C. for wards made a combined movement and Hsy. passed out to Cheesman, who shot a welldeserved goal from a difficult angle. A few minates later half time was called. During most of this half and the rest of the game the Sporting Clab played one man abort, one of their forwards having met with an accident just after the start.

Oa resuming the game the Sporting Club at once made an unexpected rash and a shot was taken but ineffectually, and play then took place around the E.T.C. goal and throngh at misunderstanding between two of the players the ball was left alone in front of the goal and. of course, one of the-Sporting Club forwards scored easily. Both sides started again with renewed vigour and the Sporting Club often looked dangerous, but their chances were not taken to fall advantage and their abooting at times was not good. Towards the end of the game they were pressing, and while defending an E.T.C. half penalised his side for "band" within the penalty area and luckily for them uo score resulted from the kick. After more even play and occasional roshes by both sides time was called for the end of a pleasant game.
